slides.title: The Art of Chili
slides.notes: Welcome to our exploration of chili, one of the most beloved comfort foods. Whether you're a traditionalist or an innovator, there's a perfect chili recipe waiting for you.

slides.title: Chili Styles Around the World
slides.notes: Chili has evolved differently in various regions. Texas purists insist on no beans, while Cincinnati serves it Greek-influenced over pasta. Chile verde showcases the amazing flavor of roasted green chiles.

slides.title: Essential Ingredients
slides.notes: Quality ingredients make the difference between good chili and great chili. Use whole spices when possible and toast them lightly before grinding for maximum flavor.

slides.title: Meat Selection
slides.notes: Don't limit yourself to ground meat. Cubed chuck or brisket creates fork-tender pieces that hold up beautifully during long simmering. Mix meats for complexity.

slides.title: Beans: Yes or No?
slides.notes: This debate has passionate advocates on both sides. The truth? Both versions are delicious. Make what you enjoy, and don't let anyone tell you it's not real chili.

slides.title: The Secret

content.text: Great chili is about layers of flavor built slowly, not just heat.

slides.notes: Rushing chili produces flat, one-dimensional flavor. Each step, from browning meat to blooming spices, adds another layer of complexity that develops during the long simmer.

slides.title: Cooking Techniques
slides.notes: Never crowd the pan when browning, or you'll steam instead of sear. Toast your spices in the rendered fat until fragrant. Patience during simmering develops flavors that can't be rushed.

slides.title: Pro Tips

callouts.heading: Secret Ingredient
callouts.text: Add a square of dark chocolate in the last 30 minutes for incredible depth.

callouts.heading: Liquid Upgrade
callouts.text: Replace half the stock with dark beer for added complexity.

callouts.heading: Salt Timing
callouts.text: Add salt at the end. Reducing intensifies saltiness during cooking.

slides.notes: These tricks come from years of competition cooking. The chocolate adds a subtle richness without sweetness. Stout or porter beers work especially well with beef chili.

slides.title: Toppings and Pairings
slides.notes: Set up a topping bar and let everyone customize. Some like it loaded, some prefer it pure. Fresh lime wedges and sliced jalape√±os are excellent additions.

slides.title: Get Cooking!
slides.notes: Chili is forgiving and personal. Your perfect bowl might be different from anyone else's, and that's the beauty of it. Start cooking, keep experimenting, and enjoy the journey!
